description.narrative: The project proposes to strengthen national statistical capacity to monitor SDG progress by developing an SDG monitoring strategy
capital of a political entity

activity-description.narrative: SDGs monitoring

description.narrative: - List of national SDG indicators available – Yes / No -Plan for introducing new indicators for SDG monitoring prepared and approved and integrated into the next Strategic Plan of the State Statistics Committee -SDG Monitoring Strategy available and approved by the State Statistics Committee – Yes/No

comment.narrative: -SDG indicators not nationalized and not produced systematically. -National capacity is inadequate for comprehensive monitoring of SDGs -Except for the newly established Department on Sustainable Development and partial list of SDG indicators, the overall institutional framework on SDG data collection and monitoring is lacking.

-List of national SDG indicators produced and included in annual plan of statistical works -Plan for introducing new indicators for SDG monitoring prepared and approved and integrated into the next Strategic Plan of the State Statistics Committee -SDG Monitoring Strategy is developed and submitted for government follow-up

-The inventory of available data looking into availability, relevance, quality, level of disaggregation, feasibility of producing new data including gender-disaggregated data and innovative approaches (using Data Ecosystem approach tested in Moldova) was undertaken. -The final list of SDG indicators will be produced by the end of December January 2018 -The Task force of national experts to lead the process of strategy development with support of international consultant was not established due to changes of State Statistical Committee’s priorities. The development the national SDG monitoring Strategy was postponed due to the need of creation of the National Information Portal on SDGs as the platform for the strategy development. The portal is working in the test mode. -The gender analysis of relevant targets and indicators was undertaken. Recommendations for mainstreaming gender into country-specific SDG framework and further SDG monitoring strategy will be made after the final prioritization and localisation of SDGs. -The conceptual framework and format of the National Informational Portal on SDGs indicators was established. The official presentation of the Portal is planned to be launched in January 2018.

comment.narrative: Baseline 1.1 The pilot area lacks efficient mechanism for providing information and skills necessary for strengthening economic participation of rural women Baseline 1.2 There is a shortage of information regarding employment opportunities and demands of local labour market. Baseline 1.3 Many rural women lack skills required by the local labour market. Baseline 1.4 Low awareness regarding the benefits of women's economic participation among general population. Baseline 1.5. Rural women lack incentives and resources to start-up small businesses Baseline 2.1 Women in the Sabirabad region are not dynamically involved in community based activism and presence of Women NGOs. Baseline 2.2 Low awareness regarding the benefits of women's soda! participation among general population. Baseline 3.1 Currently financial services are not sensitized to the needs of rural women entrepreneurs and local private employers are not aware of the potential of rural women as prospective employees. Baseline 4.1 The SCFWCA's staff requires further capacity development in policy and program development for addressing the needs of rural women. Baseline 5. There is a shortage of information regarding the problems and opportunities shaping local environment for economic empowerment and social participation of rural women in various regions on Azerbaijan.

description.narrative: To reduce the vulnerability of the communities of the Greater Caucasus GC region of Azerbaijan to water stress and hazards by improved water and flood management
Number and Type of adaptation actions implemented in national development frameworks AMAT Outcome Indicator 111

comment.narrative: 0 Normative Legal Acts NLA water code does not have IWRM relevant normative legal acts 0 NLA water code does not have relevant normative legal acts 0 NLA water code does not have relevant normative legal acts 0 NLA water code does not have relevant normative legal acts

1 NLA IWRM principles integrated in water policy 1 NLA Flood zoning regulations introduced in water code 1 NLA Conjunctive water management part of the water policy 1 NLA Public participation and gender representation rules as part of the water and flood management policy

Legal Working Group LWG was established on 25 April 2014 and from this date several meetings were held to discuss current legislation and possible changes In NLA Legal expert has prepared 12 draft proposals and 5 recommendations to Water Code Law on Environmental Protection Law On Amelioration and Irrigation Law on Ecology Safety Law on Water Supply and Wastewater Law on Water Management in Municipalities All proposal was submitted to Legal Working group and this is now under discussion During reporting period project team held 3 meetings of the LWG to conduct discussions on proposed changes to NLA Project also hired an international legal expert to bring international best practices to national legislation Report on International Legislative and Policy Best Practice in Integrated Water Resources Management as Applicable to Azerbaijan was developed and based on this report currently national and international legal experts are working on development of the new strategy to integrate and adopt IWRM and CWM principles to the NLAs List of the LWG members is attached

description.narrative: of hectares in the GC affected by improved CRM practices

comment.narrative: Zero There are no programs in place currently focused on improving climate risk management in the areas of flood and water management
Improved climate risk management affecting over 22067 sq km 2206700 ha of land in highly vulnerable region of Greater Caucasus

After replacing of CTA in 2014methodology was revised and updated work plan was prepared In accordance with the workplan the project team conducted twelve successful training sessions see page 6 on modeling and other related topics Now to reduce the vulnerability of the Greater Caucasus GC region of Azerbaijan 3 local modelers have been trained in the use of the SOBEK model hydraulic model to forecast flood events and based on the result of the model conducts risk analysis All collected data was collated and placed on the central computer server installed in the project office Currently all experts have access to the database are able to use this in the preparation of their deliverables GIS expert in cooperation with national geologist national hydrogeologist national modeler national hydrologist and lead institutional capacity expert prepared drafts of several types of maps which are evaluate and assesses risks Also project team prepared Project Atlas where they briefly show the main activities and progress During the reporting period the FFEWS specialist developed a new design and Terms of Reference for a full FFEWS in the Pilot Catchments As a part of the full system the project has developed Design of communitybased FFEWS in consultation with local communities as a pilot area in Turyanchay RB
Once funding is available and the system is installed a total of approximately 300000 hectares will benefit in the Turyanchay basin
With minor corrections proposed by the local stakeholders the concept was agreed with communities and report describing the proposed FFS implementation and operation of the FFS was developed Currently the project is working on the adaptation of this concept to the whole region
The Project has also identified and prepared a report on Requirements for Flood Forecasting Models for Project Basins Modelling Scope for a fully Integrated FFEWS The Project also prepared a detailed specification of equipment required for communitybased schemes for the 3 pilot basins The HECHMS hydrologic model was selected as being the most appropriate to use in current study Project has already conducted trainings on HECHMS provided by lead hydrologisthydraulic structure engineer and set up the HECHMS model for the Turyanchay River catchment During reporting period Water Resources EngineerIWRM Expert and National Lead Institutional Capacity Development ExpertGenderStakeholder EngagementParticipatory Specialist developed Draft institutional Integrated Water Resources Management IWRM framework and submitted it to the government officials Ministry of Emergency Situations The same time IWRM expert held three training sessions on IWRM Conceptual modelling IWRM CWM IWRM practice Climate change aspects and Conjunctive water management

description.narrative: of people who benefit from locally tailored CRM practices for flood and water risk management

comment.narrative: Zero There are no locally tailored climate change adaptation practices in place
10000000 people benefit from improved CRM practices across the GC region

Conducted studies revealed the most vulnerable communities in terms of susceptibility to waterflood risks Balakan district Mazim village Khanifa village Katekhchay village Poshtbina village Zagatala district Zaqatala city Ashgi Tala Goyam village Suvagil village Mazikh village Ititala village Ashagi Chardakhli village Uzungazmalar village Mughanli village Gakh district Gakh city Gashgachay village Gum village Almali village Zayam village Alibayli village Sheki district Sheki city Shirinbulag village Okhut village Bash Goynuk village Ashagi Goynuk village Ashagi Shabalid Selbasan village Kish village Oghuz district Filfilli village Khachmaz village Bash Dashagil village Mukhas village Bujag village Gabala district Gabala city Bum settlement Khirkhatala village Uludash village Mikhligovag village Tikanli village Hamzali village Jighatelli village Vandam village Abrikh villageGamarvan village
Once the flood forecasting and communitybased early warning system is implemented a total of approximately 211000 persons will benefit
After a wellattended Workshop on Flood Forecasting and Early Warning Systems for Local Stakeholders on 16 July 2014 the project team decide to hold meetings with communities in smaller groups community based to discuss and identify the specific needs of each group Project team held a total of 35 meetings with communities in the field and have already started to formulate CRM measure adapted to local conditions and tailored for specific communities throughout the project area Currently the project is preparing a second workshop with the communities on 5 August to evaluate all results on FFEWS and to have discussions with the communities on CWM plans Project is planning to engage around 100 participants

description.narrative: Community resilience to floods and water stress improved by introducing locally tailored climate risk management practices
Number of Local Stakeholder Committees with at least 20 women representation

comment.narrative: Zero There are no such LSCs in place

By end of Year 2 at least 3 Local MultiStakeholder Committees LSCs actively involved with regional administration in addressing climate change responses and water stress and flood damage mitigation 6 by end of year 4 and 9 by end of project all with at least 20 women membership

Again awareness building is an important component of this Local Stakeholder Committee for Turyanchay is consulted for FFEWS and will be strengthened for IWRM awareness For today project established 5 WUAs in Turyanchay RB and now work on strengthening of the knowledge and capacity through meeting and trainings for them Currently project start to establish WUA in Kishchay RB and first meetings was conducted on 2123 May with three communities To build strong relations between beneficiary and communities project involved to the meetings MoES and Regional Center specialist
The project has prepared a list of potential risk reduction and contingency measures that could be implemented locally These will be discussed with local stakeholder groups and appropriate measures to be implemented will be agreed Not all measures will be appropriate to all communities or hazards Delivery mechanisms anticipated will be via a combination of NGOs local government agencies and the communities themselvesAs a result of gender empowerment at least 3050 of the WUAs is women

At least 5 by end of year 2 10 by end of year 4 and 15 by end of project At least 20 women in all pilot WUAs by end of project

At the recommendation of the project MidTerm review the focus of the project activities was adjusted There was a pressing need for the adoption of adaptive management since a number of factors assumed in the original project document were either invalid or based on findings somewhat impractical The strengthening of the WUAs was particularly noted Awareness among existing WUAs is low and introducing high technology tools such as SWAT at this early stage was considered premature and unlikely to be practical The concentration for WUA strengthening will be an awareness building It will take some time to convert the existing WUAs irrigation focused to full water management activities and the awareness building will lead to this objective

flood zoning regulations included in flood and river management level of action local and ocmmunity level covering 400km of the target river body conjunctive water management model developed national local and community level

The Lead Water Resources Specialist has developed the WEAP Water Evaluation and Planning model using previously collected data This has been produced for the Turyanchay basin and is now producing preliminary results on water availability and the introduction of conjunctive water management through the incorporation of the groundwater component
Engagement with IPs has been difficult from the outset of the project Reasons for this can be attributed in part to the change of Ministry from Ecology to Emergency Situations This has provoked confusion over responsibilities and obligations Only now with concrete proposals for installation of Hydromet equipment on the table has a significant degree of engagement with SAWR manifested Without a deeper level of commitment and engagement by this Agency the project will experience difficulty in securing the inclusion of adaptation measures into development frameworks This activity requires action and engagement from both project and Agency and depends to a large extent on timing of the establishment of development frameworks given that the precise role of the Agency is still under discussion It is hoped that the projects proposals for institutional development of SAWR will accelerate this discussion

Draft proposals to Water Code which must support nonstructural climate change adaptation practices and integrated water resource management have been prepared and submitted to the Legal Working Group To study of the international practices on water resources management in 2014 the project hired international legalpolicy expert By the results of the work international legalpolicy expert prepared report on International Legislative and Policy Best Practice in Integrated Water Resources Management as Applicable to Azerbaijan The report is divided into five main sections Methodology Water Governance in Azerbaijan Integrating IWRM into Law IWRM Legislative and Policy Best Practices and Recommendations for Azerbaijan It is then followed by Annexes providing examples of provisions from the national legislation of select countries that reference the various best practices In order to prepare the final text of the proposal to current NLAs at the end of August 2015 it is planned to rehire international legalpolicy

The decrease in the donor funding for the marine protected areas is explained by the fact that donor funding varies between years depending on the particular activities and expenses planned for that particular year In some years there is an increase and in some years some decrease in donor funding depending on particular steps This decrease is not an indicator of diminishing attention to the marine protected areas on the side of donors
In turn the small decrease in the entry fees is explained mainly by the exchange rate change between USD and the local currency The decrease is attributed mainly to the exchange rate change Current 2611 by taking into account 34 local currency devaluation would bring current fees to 3499 AzN slightly below the baseline amount of 3902 Also not forget that the number of tourists also varies between years therefore depending on many trivial reasons like weather during holiday period or something else Still the MENR pays attention to this issue and the last year made necessary changes in the regulation allowing now for visitors to buy entrance tickets directly from the National parks The MENR understands that such a low entrance fee collection is unsatisfactory and takes measures to increase the entrance fee collection by using propaganda and easing access to the sites

Following the Project Steering Committee meeting a Substantive Project revision was prepared and approved.

1. Monitoring of implementation and follow up of “Concept Note on Introduction of e-Participation” in Azerbaijan is prepared. 2. Handbook/manual on improving access of population to government data is prepared and submitted to government institutions. 3. The “National Concept Note on Knowledge-based and Innovative Economy” is developed. 4. Selected Azerpost offices are equipped with PCs or booths; trainings are delivered to Post Offices’ employees. 5. The 5th Regional Internet Governance Forum is launched.

1. International expert prepared Monitoring Report of the "E-Participation Opportunities Analysis in Azerbaijan". In the scope of the project component in order to improve active usage of e-participation the project have organized workshops in Guba and Ganja on Universal Value Wikipedia: Wiki Management (number of participants over hundred). 2. The. ToR for the international consultant for preparation of the Handbook/manual on improving access of population to Open Government Data is prepared and consultant will be hired in 2018. 3. An international consultant was hired to draft the “National Concept Note on Knowledge-based and Innovative Economy”. The Concept will be reviewed by the Ministry in 2018. 4. The have hired a local expert for preparation of the “Electron Azerbaijan” handbook. Trainings on e-government for local authorities, business and civil societies in the regions of Azerbaijan, Ganja and Guba (number of participants more than hundred) were organized. Selected Azerpost offices will be equipped in 2018. 5. The Regional Internet Governance Forum website was updated and redesigned. The 5th Regional Internet Governance Forum Baku, Azerbaijan (RIGFAZ 2017) under the slogan of “Internet as the key to innovation and prosperity" on 7th December 2017 was organized with participation of more than 150 people from ICT society.

comment.narrative: Medium extent (=3).

- Baseline assessment of training, equipment, and infrastructural needs of relevant departments is in place and used for developments of the detailed action plan - 12 training and workshop activities to enrich skills and knowledge of Border officials - 114 border guards trained - National IBM concept introduced - Bilateral agreements between two sate regulating cooperation in border management improved - Requested equipment is delivered to partners - Relevant infrastructural assistance is provided

- Baseline assessment of training, equipment, and infrastructural needs of relevant departments carried with assistance from ICMPD - 12 training and workshop activities conducted with assistance from ICMPD and FRONTEX - 114 border guards trained - National IBM concept is drafted and pending final approval by the Government - Bilateral cooperation between two sates in border management improved through development of the draft agreements on operation of border delegates that is expected to be finalized in February 2017 - Requested equipment in total amount of 271,981.09 (USD) is delivered to partners - Tenders for providing o the Relevant infrastructural assistance was posted, activities will be finalized in 2017.
Capacity building activities conducted; Protocol on coordinated patrol of the border between AZE and GEO developed; At least one study tour conducted.

- A total of 5 capacity building activities were implemented within the project in 2017 so far, totally 48 representatives of relevant Azerbaijani border authorities participated in workshops; - 2 study tours to Spain (May 22-25, 2017) and Finland (September 11-14, 2017) were organized to familiarise senior representatives from Azerbaijan and Georgia the work and tasks of border agencies, as well as with Integrated Border Management. The visits focused on facilitation on international cooperation namely border delegates institution. - Additional equipment to the State Border Service have been procured to increase its technical capacities in implementation of regular duties. - Closing conference was organized on September 25, 2017 to present the project outputs and plan future activities.

description.narrative: Defence - policy, planning and administration

1) Number of Common capacity building activities carried out; 2) Red Bridge BCP to meet international and EU SPS standards and functional on both sides of the border 3) Awareness on EUMSs best practice on SPS controls at BCPs Systematic SPS trainings for staff 4) SPS facilities and equipment are in place 5) 525 traffic means per day according to the statistical data provided by SCC and RS (year tbc) 6) Fenced off control area constructed according to international standards, Systematic SPS control according to international standards on place 7) SPS facilities and equipment are in place, Systematic SPS control according to international standards on place

comment.narrative: 1) No common capacity building activities in area of SPS 2) SPS checks at Red Bridge are not conducted in full compliance with international and EU regulations 3) Limited awareness on EUMSs best practice on SPS controls at BCPs 4) SPS facilities and equipment outdated or does not exist; ad hoc SPS control 5) No systematic average traffic flow control per day on Red Bridge Check Point 6) No fenced off control area 7) SPS facilities and equipment outdated or does not exist; ad hoc SPS control

- At least 10 common capacity building activities carried out - SPS equipment based on international standards procured, installed and available, - Necessary trainings for SCC and RS staff on SPS and veterinary border controls - At least 10 AZ staff and 10 GE staff participated in Study visits to EU countries - SPS facilities are constructed and equipped; necessary trainings for RS and SCC staff on new equipment conducted - At least 650 traffic means pass the Red Bridge Check point per day by 2018 - Fenced off control area constructed and secured storage/sampling area in place; necessary trainings for SCC on sampling equipment conducted

- Training Needs for Azerbaijan SCC and Georgia Revenue Service assessed. - Number of training programmes for key personnel of Azerbaijan SCC and Georgian RS on General SPS Control Checks at Border Crossing Posts; Phyto-sanitary (Plant Health) Issues, Veterinary (animal health) Issues and Food Safety - records and feedback from training sessions, evaluation and training monitoring reports delivered. - Study Tour to EUMs to demonstrate best practice on SPS controls at BCPs organized. - SPS equipment based on international standards procured and available. - Over 90 customs specialists have attended the trainings organized within the project activity. - Letter of Agreement signed between SCC Academy and UNDP project. - Model Plan of the customs area terminal complex designed.

- At least 10 common capacity building activities carried out - At least 10 AZE staff and 10 GEO staff participated in Study visits to EU countries - At least 650 traffic means pass the Red Bridge Check Point per day by 2018 - Fenced off control area constructed and secured storage/sampling area in place; necessary trainings for SCC on sampling equipment conducted

- Systematic national and bilateral trainings/workshops/seminars for Azerbaijan SCC and Georgian RS personnel on general SPS, veterinary controls and food safety at BCPs carried out; Over 250 customs specialists attended the trainings/workshops organized within the project activity; - Study Tour to Lithuania was organised on 21-28 April, 2017 to get EU best practice on food safety, SPS and veterinary controls at borders. Lithuania State Food and Veterinary Service, Lithuania Customs Service and State Plant Service under the Ministry of Agriculture of Lithuania hosted the Azerbaijan SCC delegation headed by SCC Deputy Chief. 5 high level officials participated at ST to get Lithuanian experience in the field of SPS, veterinary and food safety controls at BCPs. The members of delegation were also informed about new technologies, standards, regulations and working practice on traffic safety of bio materials, plants, food and live animals through national and EU borders. - Appx.620 traffic means pass the RB BCP per day by the end of 2017 - On 18 September, 2017 UNDP announced a bid on “Construction of Fence and Customs Trade Facilitation Operation Unit at Red Bridge BCP” through e-tendering, deadline of which was 20 October. “Shinkar Holding” LLC won the tender and the case was approved by RACP. The contract was signed between UNDP Project and “Shinkar Holding” LLC in total amount of 567 403 USD for TFOU and Fence Construction. The construction works will be completed in 2018.

1. Enhancing skills and competencies of academic staff of ATMU through international experience (organization of trainings). 2. Establishment of laboratories for Tourism and Hospitality Faculty of ATMU (purchase of necessary equipment). 3. Preparation of Strategic Plan 2016-2024 for ATMU. 4. Support ATMU in obtaining UNWTO TedQual Certification of the faculty of Tourism and Hospitality. 5. Organization of professional trainings for prospective personnel for tourism industry.

1. The Project hired an international consultant to conduct a training course on “Management Consultancy” for the academic staff of the ATMU on December 16-22, 2016. 17 participants (11 women and 6 men) from the Management Department, International Relations Department and Economic Department have attended the training course. 2. After the budget reduction due to the devaluation, after discussions with the Ministry of Culture and Tourism and the ATMU, it was decided to establish only one laboratory in ATMU. The activity will be implemented in 2017. 3. The Project has contracted international and local expert to support ATMU in preparation of the Strategic Plan 2016-2024. During their assignment the consultants recommended to prepare the four-year Strategic Plan instead of eight-year. The issue was discussed with the ATMU Management and it was agreed to prepare the Strategic Plan of the ATMU for 2016-2020. The Recommendations for new Strategic Plan of the ATMU were prepared and the report was handed over to the ATMU. 4. The Project communicated to UNWTO Themis Foundation regarding the UNWTO TedQual Certification of the Faculty of the Tourism and Hospitality of the ATMU and received necessary documentation for initiation of the Certification Process. The documents containing the information about current situation of the ATMU were prepared and sent back to the UNWTO Themis Foundation for review. Upon the decision of the Foundation, it was recommended to start UNWTO TedQual Pre-Audit Process. The Agreement between UNDP and UNWTO Themis Foundation was signed in December 2016. The visit of representatives of the Themis Foundation to the ATMU is planned for February 2017. 5. The Project contracted a company to organize 3 months’ trainings for perspective tourism personnel (for guides, receptionists, waiters/bartenders). Besides the specialized subjects, trainings on psychology, ethics, aesthetics, English and Russian Languages were organized. Total number of tra

1. Organization of trainings for ATMU academic staff. 2. Purchase and translation of modern tutorials. 3. Establishment of laboratory for the Faculty of the Tourism and Hospitality of the ATMU. 4. Cooperation with UNWTO Themis Foundation on UNWTO TedQual Certification of the Faculty of Tourism and Hospitality of the ATMU: • Pre-Audit Process to be conducted by the Consultant of UNWTO Themis Foundation in February 2017. • The UNWTO.TedQual Pre-audit report with the corresponding recommendations for improvement to be provided till May 2017 • Further steps for certification to be determined after the results of pre-audit process 5. Organization of the study tour of the academic and/or managerial staff to the international tourism educational institution.

• The modern tutorials and manuals have been purchased and handed over to the ATMU. • The interactive multimedia application for guides prepared (for the establishment of the laboratory). • Pre-audit of the ATMU conducted by the consultant of the UNWTO. Themis Foundation. The report was handed over to the ATMU • Due to funds transfer delays from the Ministry, the study tour and trainings for ATMU staff will be conducted in 2018.

1) Mercury Inventory for Azerbaijan has been prepared by using Level 1 Toolkit and when necessary and appropriate Level 2 Toolkit. The team of local consultants worked in close cooperation with the lead international consultant. The results were presented in workshop in Moscow and during the COP meeting in Geneva. 2) Mercury Initial Assessment for Azerbaijan, which included also legal and institutional analysis, social and gender analysis has been prepared and published in Azeri 3) 3 types of dissemination materials were prepared and published: for general public, for policy makers and for specialists. In addition, mercury-free thermometers were purchased and disseminated during public-awareness campaign conducted across the country in schools, clinics, universities, etc.

comment.narrative: Baseline 2.1: No analysis present; Legal framework is outdated; Equipment and building of workshops are worn-out and are not usable Baseline 2.2: There is no any modern curricula in VET centre Baseline 2.3: There is no cooperation of VET system and local business on labour market requirements
Labour market study conducted

Target achieved. The study mapped the largest public and private employers in the agricultural and manufacturing sector, identified their and potential human resources needs, and determined specific skills and competences that are deficient at the labour market. The findings of the labour market study will be used for the planning and development of new curricula and modular training courses of the Jalilabad VET Lyceum.

activity-description.narrative: enhancing capacity of the ABAD regional centre in Balakan and fostering the creation of modern and sustainable family businesses in rural areas

description.narrative: policy, planning and administration

Indicator 1.1: Thirty groups of families from all the regions of the Sheki-Zaqatala Economic Zone are selected and empowered to start their businesses. Indicator 1.2: The number of ABAD staff visited EU countries to learn the European experience in developing family businesses. Indicator 2: An individually tailored pre-production and pre-sale system of family products is developed. Indicator 3: Special brands for family products are created and introduced to the market. Indicator 4: Sale channels of family products are in place.

comment.narrative: Baseline 1: No such project, which assists small entrepreneurs throughout the whole business process, has ever been carried out. Baseline 2: Families wishing to start their business lack basic financial and legal knowledge. Baseline 3: Families either lack proper production technology or have outdated ones. Baseline 4: Families either do not have access to business related services or lack financial means for that purpose.
Signing the project document with beneficiary
The project document was signed on 13 December 2017
